Compiling for Embedded Systems - Part II

Playing MIDI Files

To play a Standard MIDI File (SMF) you need to get it into memory as an unsigned char array. There are 3 ways to do that.
  1. Convert the MIDI file to 'C' source code for an unsigned char array and compile it with your program. This will work on systems that do not support file I/O or database access. An example song has been provided in the file "spmidi/examples/UpAndDown.c". We can provide a shell tool called "bintoc" that will convert SMF files to 'C'. Also the Mobileer Instrument Editor (licensed separately) can export songs and playlists as 'C' source.
  2. If you have support for file I/O on your system and want to load MIDI files into memory then use the function SPMUtil_LoadFileImage() from "spmidi/util/spmidi_load.c".
  3. Load a SMF from your ringtone database.
The file "minimal_player.c" contains an example program that uses the MIDI file contained in "spmidi/examples/UpAndDown.c". I recommend using that for testing your first player program.

At this point you should be able to play any MIDI file that is stored as a (char *) array in memory.

Ringtone Database and System Integration

The final step is to integrate the SP-MIDI Ringtone Player with your system. You may need support for:
  • downloading ringtones as SMF files,
  • storing ringtones in a database in Flash ROM,
  • previewing and selecting ringtones,
  • triggering the selected ringtone when the phone rings.
Those functions are very specific to your system and are not part of the basic Mobileer product. But we could develop such software to your specification if desired.
